data.citation: Alexander Archipenko (American, born Ukraine, 1887–1964). Family Life, 1912. Plaster; approx. h. 182.9 cm (72 in.). Destroyed.

data.title: Landscape, 1912
data.medium: Oil on canvas; 50.2 x 61.3 cm (19 3/4 x 24 1/8 in.)
data.description:
Souza Cardoso's style reflects the developments of Futurism and Cubism, whose artists he exhibited with in Europe. Here, the repeated, geometric description of form is reminiscent of Futurist "lines of force," while the palette of brown, tan, and green recalls the early Cubist landscapes of Picasso and Braque.

In Chicago, this canvas was included in the gallery reserved for the most radical works; it was hung beside one of the most vilified, Marcel Duchamp's Nude Descending a Staircase (1912; Philadelphia Museum of Art).
data.citation: Amadeo de Souza Cardoso (Portuguese, 1887–1918). Landscape, 1912. Oil on canvas; 50.2 × 61.3 cm (19 3/4 × 24 1/8 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Arthur Jerome Eddy Memorial Collection, 1931.513.

Francis Picabia (French, 1879–1953). Paris, 1912. Oil on canvas; 73 × 92 cm (28 3/4 × 36 1/4 in.).

data.title: Village, c. 1912
data.medium: Oil on canvas; 73.7 x 92.1 cm (29 x 36 1/4 in.)
data.description: Although Maurice de Vlaminck is known as one of the founders of Fauvism, he experimented briefly with Cubist aesthetics before World War I. In Village, he combined his characteristic rhythmic brushstrokes with a more muted palette than in his earlier, brilliantly hued Fauve paintings. The three works by Vlaminck included in the Armory Show in Chicago were among those lent by important Cubist art dealer Daniel-Henry Kahnweiler. Village was installed in the Cubist gallery, next to paintings by Francis Picabia, who was characterized by the Chicago press as one of the most radical artists in the show.
data.citation: Maurice de Vlaminck (French, 1876–1958). Village, c. 1912. Oil on canvas; 73.7 × 92.1 cm (29 × 36 1/4 in.). The Art Institute of Chicago, Arthur Jerome Eddy Memorial Collection, 1931.517.
